title: Influence of water-based ferrofluid upon chlorophylls in cereals
journal: Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
keyAssumptions: Magnetic materials are inert to biological systems; Traditional fertilizers are only viable nutrient delivery method
citation: Răcuciu, M., & Creangă, D. E. (2006). Influence of water-based ferrofluid upon chlorophylls in cereals. Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials, 311(1), 182-186.
notes: First demonstration of beneficial ferrofluid effects on cereal photosynthesis. Water-based ferrofluid (10-250 μL/L) with citric acid stabilization increased chlorophyll and carotenoid content in maize under 50 mT magnetic field.

title: Cytogenetic changes induced by aqueous ferrofluids in agricultural plants
journal: Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
keyAssumptions: Nanoparticles are inherently cytotoxic to plant cells
citation: Răcuciu, M., & Creangă, D. (2006). Cytogenetic changes induced by aqueous ferrofluids in agricultural plants. Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials, 311(1), 177-181.
notes: Established dose-response safety profiles for ferrofluid applications. Low concentrations (10-250 μL/L) stimulated cell division in root meristems rather than causing damage.

title: Effects of Iron Oxide Nanoparticles (Fe3O4) on Growth, Photosynthesis, Antioxidant Activity and Distribution of Mineral Elements in Wheat (Triticum aestivum) Plants
authors: Yingming Feng, Vladimir D. Kreslavski, Alexander N. Shmarev, Anatoli A. Ivanov, Svetlana K. Zharmukhamedova, Min Yu, Alexey Kosobryukhov
keyAssumptions: Only dissolved iron forms can be absorbed by plant roots
citation: Feng, Y., Kreslavski, V. D., Shmarev, A. N., Ivanov, A. A., Zharmukhamedova, S. K., Yu, M., & Kosobryukhov, A. (2022). Effects of Iron Oxide Nanoparticles (Fe3O4) on Growth, Photosynthesis, Antioxidant Activity and Distribution of Mineral Elements in Wheat (Triticum aestivum) Plants. Plants, 11(14), 1894.
notes: Demonstrated Fe₃O₄ nanoparticles increased wheat chlorophyll content (15-25%), biomass accumulation, and antioxidant enzyme activity. Established wheat as suitable model for iron nanoparticle studies.

title: Impact of magnetic field on the translocation of iron oxide nanoparticles (Fe3O4) in barley seedlings (Hordeum vulgare L.)
authors: Huseyin Tombuloglu, Ismail Ercan, Noha Alqahtani, Bayan Alotaibi, Muruj Bamhrez
keyAssumptions: Nanoparticle uptake is passive and cannot be enhanced through external means
citation: Tombuloglu, H., Ercan, I., Alqahtani, N., Alotaibi, B., & Bamhrez, M. (2023). Impact of magnetic field on the translocation of iron oxide nanoparticles (Fe3O4) in barley seedlings (Hordeum vulgare L.). 3 Biotech, 13(9), 296.
notes: Magnetic fields increased Fe₃O₄ nanoparticle translocation from roots to shoots by 40-60% in barley seedlings. Introduced concept of magnetically-guided nutrient delivery directly relevant to ferrofluid applications.

title: Iron Oxide Nanoparticles as a Potential Iron Fertilizer for Peanut (Arachis hypogaea)
authors: Mengmeng Rui, Chuanxin Ma, Yi Hao, Jing Guo, Yukui Rui, Xinlian Tang, Qi Zhao, Xing Fan, Zetian Zhang, Tianqi Hou, Siyuan Zhu
keyAssumptions: Nanoparticles will leach from sandy soils like traditional fertilizers
citation: Rui, M., Ma, C., Hao, Y., Guo, J., Rui, Y., Tang, X., ... & Zhu, S. (2016). Iron oxide nanoparticles as a potential iron fertilizer for peanut (Arachis hypogaea). Frontiers in Plant Science, 7, 815.
notes: Fe₂O₃ nanoparticles outperformed EDTA-Fe chelates in sandy soils by adsorbing to soil particles and providing sustained release. Demonstrated superior performance in challenging soil conditions.

title: Fertigation with Fe-EDTA, Fe-DTPA, and Fe-EDDHA Chelates to Prevent Iron Chlorosis of Sensitive Species in High-pH Soilless Media
authors: Julie A. Hershkowitz, Mackenzie G. Dey, Royal Heins, Bruce Bugbee
keyAssumptions: All iron chelates provide equivalent plant-available iron regardless of conditions
citation: Hershkowitz, J. A., Dey, M. G., Heins, R., & Bugbee, B. (2025). Fertigation with Fe-EDTA, Fe-DTPA, and Fe-EDDHA chelates to prevent iron chlorosis of sensitive species in high-pH soilless media. HortScience, 60(3), 404-410.
notes: Quantified pH-dependent chelate effectiveness: Fe-EDDHA (pH 9), Fe-DTPA (pH 7.5), Fe-EDTA (pH 6.5). Cost differences significant: Fe-EDDHA costs 4× Fe-EDTA. Established pH-specific chelate selection guidelines.

title: Eco-Friendly Iron-Humic Nanofertilizers Synthesis for the Prevention of Iron Chlorosis in Soybean (Glycine max) Grown in Calcareous Soil
authors: María T. Cieschi, Alexander Yu Polyakov, Vasily A. Lebedev, Dmitry S. Volkov, Denis A. Pankratov, Alexey A. Veligzhanin, Irina V. Perminova, Juan J. Lucena
keyAssumptions: Only synthetic chelates can provide stable iron delivery in alkaline soils
citation: Cieschi, M. T., Polyakov, A. Y., Lebedev, V. A., Volkov, D. S., Pankratov, D. A., Veligzhanin, A. A., ... & Lucena, J. J. (2019). Eco-friendly iron-humic nanofertilizers synthesis for the prevention of iron chlorosis in soybean (Glycine max) grown in calcareous soil. Frontiers in Plant Science, 10, 413.
notes: Iron-humic nanofertilizers showed 35% better uptake than Fe-EDDHA with 60% less environmental persistence using ⁵⁷Fe tracer studies. Demonstrated sustainable alternative to synthetic chelates.
